docs.lead_paragraph: In January 1964, when the surgeon general of the Public Health Service issued the first report on smoking and health, linking tobacco to a host of serious diseases, including and especially lung cancer, the most common statement from the many smokers I interviewed was, ''By the time I get lung cancer, they'll know how to cure it.'' Well, it is nearly 37 years later, and ''they'' still don't know how to cure lung cancer, except when the disease is detected before symptoms develop and while the tumor is still at its site of origin, a small minority of cases.

headline.main: Lung Cancer Cure? Try Prevention Instead

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on lung cancer; says doctors still do not know how to cure lung cancer except when disease is detected before symptoms develop and while tumor is still at its site of origin; doctors do know how to prevent 90 percent of cases of lung cancer--by not smoking; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prescription drugs accounted for 44 percent of the increase in health costs last year, researchers said today. In a report published in the journal Health Affairs, the researchers said overall health costs for services covered by private insurance rose by 6.6 percent last year, while drug spending increased by 18.4 percent. The study did not separately examine costs for people without insurance.

headline.main: Rise in Health Care Costs Rests Largely on Drug Prices

docs.abstract: Researchers report prescription drugs accounted for 44 percent of increase in health costs in 1999; report overall health costs for services covered by private insurance rose by 6.6 percent, while drug spending increased by 18.4 percent; Paul B Ginsburg, one of authors, says prescription drugs accounted for more of 6.6 percent increase than either hospital care or doctors' services; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Wozar family of Whitestone leaves town, they rarely bring 9-year-old Sherlock along. Instead, they rent a hotel room for him and his two siblings, with color cable television, air-conditioning, a telephone, room service and round-the-clock supervision. Sherlock is a giant schnauzer, and his siblings are two Persian cats named Kahlua and Watson. And their home away from home is Barkingham Palace in Port Washington, where vacationing dog owners can check their pets into either kennels or private rooms.

headline.main: Only the Best for Man's Best Friend. And Woman's Too.

docs.abstract: Article describes facilities and services available to dogs and their owners on Long Island, including Barkington Palace boarding kennel in Port Washington, traveling veterinarians, Pet Pantry in Roslyn Heights, day care centers and dog sitters; photos (Special Issue: The Best of Long Island) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE nation crossed a new threshold last week: the permanent campaign became the endless election. The nightly tracking polls that showed a race too close to call turned into an election too close to call, and platoons of Democratic and Republican lawyers descended on Florida to continue the fight. There was, unmistakably, a wave of anxiety in the political community: Had the partisan struggle gone too far? Was this the fearful coda -- think of the last scene of ''Carrie,'' monstrous hand coming out of the grave -- to an era that has already seen unprecedented partisan struggle over judicial nominations, various and assorted investigations of speakers, presidents and cabinet officers, and ultimately the first presidential impeachment in 130 years?

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Vacancy; Stunning Estate, 130-plus Rms., 18 Acres, Rose Garden. Available.

docs.abstract: Assessment of brutal post-election clash between Democrats and Republicans over unresolved presidential election; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For New York Republicans, Tuesday, in many ways, was a dark day that could be summed up in two words: Senator Clinton. There was no net gain in the House of Representatives, no chance to send Joan Johnson, the Islip town clerk, to Washington to be the first black Republican woman in Congress, and no president to inaugurate, at least not yet. But for Nassau County Republicans there was cause for celebration: the county's five Republican incumbents in the State Senate were re-elected after tough contests, and the party took back control of the Town Board in Hempstead, which is considered the party's hometown.

headline.main: Nassau Republicans Make a Comeback From Voter Revolt of 1999

docs.abstract: Nassau County, NY, Republicans make comeback from voter revolt of 1999; county's five Republican incumbents in State Senate are re-elected after tough contests, and party takes back control of Town Board in Hempstead, which is considered party's hometown; Republicans praise work of party chairman, Joseph N Mondello (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are many tales about Bernice Wall Barbour, and one of the favorites involves the winter when she heard that elk were starving to death out West. She left her New Jersey home and headed out to her Wyoming ranch, where she bought a snowmobile and spent the winter hauling hay to the hungry animals. Her passion for animals was so great that in 1987, two years before she died, Mrs. Barbour, a lifelong New Jersey resident, set up a foundation -- the Bernice Barbour Foundation Inc., based in Hackensack. Its mission: to give grants to groups that preserve and care for animals in the United States and to groups that prevent cruelty to animals.
docs.abstract: Article profiles some New Jersey foundations and their projects: E J Grassmann Trust, Puffin Foundation Ltd, Victoria Foundation, Pascale/Sykes Foundation Inc, Barbara Piasecka Johnson Foundation and Bernice Barbour Foundation; photos (Special Issue: Best of New Jersey) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from people with hemophilia, the Bayer Corporation said yesterday that it would stop requiring patients to apply to a special corporate program for its new drug, Kogenate FS, which is in short supply, and would instead begin distributing it through normal channels. In September, Bayer angered many hemophiliacs and their doctors by introducing the program, which requires patients to fill out an application. Under the plan, only those patients that the company approved would receive the new drug, a genetically engineered version of the blood-clotting factor that hemophiliacs need to survive. At that time, company executives said that Bayer did not want extra inventory of the drug held at pharmacies when it was in short supply.
docs.abstract: Bayer Corp will stop requiring hemophilia patients to apply to special corporate program for its new drug, Kogenate FS, which is in short supply, and will instead begin distributing it through normal channels; under program being abandoned, which angered many hemophiliacs and their doctors, only those patients that company approved would receive new drug, genetically engineered version of blood-clotting factor that hemophiliacs need to survive (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK BROOKLYN: GOTTI RELATIVE SAYS F.B.I. LIED Lawyers for Carmine Agnello, left, the son-in-law of the former crime boss John Gotti, said yesterday that an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation lied when he said that Mr. Agnello had threatened an informer during a meeting with Anthony Federici, a member of the Genovese crime family. In a signed affidavit filed on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, where Mr. Agnello is facing arson and extortion charges, Mr. Federici said he had never met with Mr. Agnello. In March, an F.B.I. agent said Mr. Agnello made a threatening hand gesture during the meeting and that Mr. Agnello should therefore be jailed before trial, and he was. Prosecutors declined to comment on the allegations. Alan Feuer (NYT) QUEENS: CHARGES OF BROTHEL PROTECTION A city police officer was charged yesterday with providing protection for a brothel and gambling den that catered mainly to Chinese-speaking patrons in Flushing, Queens. According to papers filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, the officer, Jay Zhao, helped two federal undercover agents posing as Chicago businessmen hire prostitutes from the brothel. The papers also said that Officer Zhao, who has been suspended from his job at the 78th Precinct, worked inside the brothel. His lawyer declined to comment. Alan Feuer (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: California's enormous prison system, the largest in the Western Hemisphere with more than 162,000 inmates, may be radically altered since voters on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a measure that will sentence nonviolent drug offenders to treatment instead of prison. Nearly one in three prisoners in California is serving time for a drug-related crime, more per capita than any other state. The new law, Proposition 36, puts California at the forefront of a national movement to change drug laws; it will send first- and second-time nonviolent drug offenders into treatment, reducing the prison population by as many as 36,000 inmates a year, according to the state's nonpartisan Legislative Analyst's Office.

headline.main: California Gets Set to Shift On Sentencing Drug Users

docs.abstract: California voters overwhelmingly approve measure that will sentence nonviolent drug offenders to treatment instead of prison; nearly one in three prisoners in state is serving time for drug-related crime, more per capital than any other state; new law, Proposition 36, puts California at forefront of national movement to change drug laws; it will send first- and second-time nonviolent drug offenders into treatment, reducing prison population by as many as 36,000 inmates a year; measure was approved by 61 percent of voters despite strong opposition from virtually all of state's law enforcement officials, judges and some health care groups; photo (M)
